docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans live with macular degeneration, a leading cause of vision loss among older people, and Stargardt's disease, a similar condition that arises in late childhood. Stephen Rose, chief research officer for the Foundation Fighting Blindness, recently joined the Consults blog to answer reader questions about these retinal degenerative diseases. Here, Dr. Rose responds to reader questions about potential treatments for macular degeneration and Stargardt's disease that are currently under investigation.
docs.abstract: Stephen Rose of the Foundation Fighting Blindness responds to reader questions about treatments now under investigation for macular degeneration and Stargardt's disease.
docs.snippet: Stephen Rose of the Foundation Fighting Blindness responds to reader questions about treatments now under investigation for macular degeneration and Stargardt's disease.

docs.lead_paragraph: As Washington looks to squeeze savings from once-sacrosanct entitlements like Social Security and Medicare, another big social welfare system is growing as rapidly, but with far less scrutiny: the health and pension benefits of military retirees. Military pensions and health care for active and retired troops now cost the government about $100 billion a year, representing an expanding portion of both the Pentagon budget -- about $700 billion a year, including war costs -- and the national debt, which together finance the programs.

headline.main: Retiree Plans For Military Face Scrutiny

docs.abstract: Intense push in Congress to reduce national debt increases vulnerability of health and pension benefits for military retirees, which cost government about $100 billion a year; charts; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Marin County has had far fewer whooping cough cases this year thanks to an intensive public education campaign, free vaccine clinics and a new state requirement that all middle and high school students have up-to-date vaccinations.
